sen.e: In the Boshin War, he was appointed the army commander of Tosa Domain and the staff officer of the spearhead governor of Tosan-do Road, smashing Shinsengumi led by Isami KONDO in the Battle of Koshu-Katsunuma.

sen.j: これは新政府において、木戸孝允（長州藩）、西郷隆盛（薩摩藩）、大隈重信（佐賀藩）と共に、"第一期"での参与就任であった。
sen.e: He was the one of those who assumed the post of Sanyo of the "first term" in the new government, along with Takayoshi KIDO (Choshu Domain), Takamori SAIGO (Satsuma Domain), and Shigenobu OKUMA (Saga Domain).

sen.e: Namely, in the new government led by the four domain cliques of Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa, and Hizen, these four people including Itagaki were the highest ranking feudal retainers representing each of their domains.

sen.e: In 1873, Itagaki advocated Seikanron (debate on subjugation of Korea), but eventually gave in to Tomomi IWAKURA and other returnees from the visitation to the West who took a prudent stance considering the international relationships with Europe and America, resulting in the split of the new government.

sen.e: In 1881, upon the issuance of the Imperial Decree that the Imperial Diet be inaugurated ten years later, Itagaki formed the Liberal Party (Japan, 1881-1884), one of Japan's first political parties, to become the prime minister (party leader).

sen.e: In April 1882, Itagaki was attacked by a thug named Naobumi AIHARA to get injured while he was campaigning in Gifu City (the Gifu incident).

sen.j: その際、「板垣死すとも自由は死せず」と叫んだ。
sen.e: "Itagaki may die, but liberty never!" he shouted at that moment.
"Itagaki may die, but liberty never will!" he shouted at that moment.
"Itagaki may die, but liberty never will!" he shouted at that moment.

sen.j: これは事件の直後、小室信介（案外堂。1852 - 1885.8.25）というジャーナリストが岐阜で行った演説の題名「板垣死ストモ自由ハ死セズ」が、板垣自身の発言として世間に広まったものである。
sen.e: Although this was widely regarded as Itagaki's own remark, the phrase actually came from a speech titled "Itagaki may die, but liberty never!" made by a journalist Shinsuke KOMURO (also called himself as Angaido, 1852 - August 25, 1885) in Gifu prefecture right after the incident.

sen.j: これには異説もあり、当時板垣の秘書であった内藤魯一という人物が事件現場で叫んだとも言われる。

sen.j: 板垣は後藤の才を見抜き「彼を政治家にできないのが残念だ」と語った。
sen.e: Itagaki discerned Goto's ability, saying "It's a pity that I cannot make you a politician."

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）10月、自由民権運動の激化で加波山事件が起き、自由党を一旦解党した。
sen.e: In October 1884, intensifying Jiyu Minken Undo culminated in the incident of Mt. Kaba (a failed terror attack attempt and subsequent harsh crackdown on activists of Jiyu Minken Undo in Tochigi Prefecture), prompting Itagaki to dissolve Liberal Party for the time being.
sen.cmt: 加波山事件：左記のように（）で補足しました。
sen.e: In October 1884, intensifying Jiyu Minken Undo culminated in the incident of Mt. Kaba (a failed terror attack attempt and subsequent harsh crackdown on activists of Jiyu Minken Undo in Tochigi Prefecture), prompting Itagaki to dissolve the Liberal Party for the time being.

In October 1884, intensifying Jiyu Minken Undo culminated in the Kabasan Incident (a failed terror attack attempt and subsequent harsh crackdown on activists of Jiyu Minken Undo in Ibaraki and Tochigi Prefectures), prompting Itagaki to dissolve the Liberal Party for the time being.
sen.cmt: 加波山事件の英訳（用語集による）加波山は茨城県なので茨城も加えたほうが良いと思います。

sen.e: Therefore, this cabinet was also commonly called Waihan Cabinet (representing the combination of each one Kanji character from Okubo and Itagaki, that is "隅" and "板").

sen.j: 大正8年（1919年）7月16日薨去。

sen.j: 板垣は日本の民主主義発展に大きな功績を残したが、彼自身は無欲恬淡、金銭欲も淡白でしたたかさがなく（端的に言えば「いい人」）、清濁合わせ呑むことが要求される政治家としては必ずしも有能だったとは言えない。
sen.e: While there is no doubt that Itagaki immensely contributed to the growth of Japan's democracy, however, because of his selfless character with no thirst for money and with no wiliness (that is to say, he was simply "a nice person"), he was not necessarily an adept politician, a profession that requires to be broad-minded enough to deal with all sorts of good and evil.

sen.j: 慶応4年（1868年）新政府東山道先鋒総督府参謀として進軍していた退助は、天領（旧幕府領）の甲府城に掌握を目前に、美濃国大垣に着いた2月14日が、板垣信方の没後320年にあたるため、先祖の旧姓とする板垣姓に改姓した。
sen.e: In 1868, while marching his troops as the counselor of Tosando-Road spearhead government-general of the new government, he changed his family name back to Itagaki, the one his ancestors had proclaimed, as February 14, the day they arrived in Ogaki in Mino Province just before seizing Kofu Castle in a shogunal demesne, coincidently marked the 320th anniversary of the death of his grandfather Nobukata ITAGAKI.

sen.e: With the act, Itagaki intended to gain support from Kai people, by reminding them that he was a member of the Inui clan succeeding the Itagaki clan that derived from Kai-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.e: As he expected, the change of his family name earned Itagaki the tremendous support from Kai people, leading to his landslide victory at the Battle of Koshu-Katsunuma.

sen.j: 抜刀術は故郷に伝わる無双直伝英信流谷村派を、後に第17代となる大江正路と共に修めていた。
sen.e: Itagaki mastered the battojutsu (the technique of drawing a sword) of Muso Jikiden Eishin Ryu school Tanimura Sect that had been transmitted in his hometown with Masamichi OE, who later became the 17th headmaster.

sen.j: 乾氏（板垣氏） 江戸時代、代々土佐藩士で、家格は馬廻役（上士）。
sen.e: The Inui clan (the Itagaki clan) was hereditary feudal retainers of Tosa Domain in the Edo period, with the social standing of Umamawariyaku (body guard), a Joshi status (superior warrior).

sen.e: Its family crest were "kayanouchi jumonji"(the end of Sengoku Period [period of warring states] to the mid Meiji Period), and "tosagiri"(after the mid Meiji Period).

sen.j: - 山全体が乾氏専用の大きな墓地となっており,初代正信から退助までの10代の墓石が整然とあり,退助の墓は三番目の妻小谷氏と並んで建てられている。
sen.e: The whole mountain is like a big graveyard dedicated for the Inui clan, with the gravestones aligned in a orderly fashion for ten generations from Masanobu, the first head of the family, to Taisuke, whose gravestone stands next to the one of his third wife, Mrs. Odani.
